elements.content: Three uranyl phthalates have been hydrothermally synthesized (200 °C, 24 h) and characterized by means of single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The compound UO2(H2O)(1,2-bdc)·0.32H2O (1,2-bdc = phthalate) crystallizes at low pH (0.9−1.5). Its structure is built up from pentagonal bipyramids (UO2)O4(H2O) linked to each other through the phthalate groups and defines infinite nanotubular 1D motifs delimited by six uranyl centers. The two other compounds A(UO2)3O(OH)(H2O)(1,2-bdc)2 (A = K, NH4) are formed for higher pH (1.5−3). They are isostructural and consist of the 1D connection of dinuclear units (UO2)2O4(μ2-OH)2(H2O)2 with tetranuclear units (UO2)4(μ3-O)2O12 via the phthalate groups. The cationic A species are intercalated between the mixed organic−inorganic chains. Discussion of the formation of these different phases was given as a function of pH.

elements.content: Depending on the reaction pH, two types of uranyl phthalates with one-dimensional networks have been isolated. They consist of either infinite six-membered ring nanotubes (pH = 0.9−1.5) or connections of dinuclear and tetranuclear motifs (pH = 1.5−3), indicating the oligomerization process when pH increases.

elements.content: A considerable interest has been focused on the synthesis of mixed organic−inorganic architectures exhibiting extended networks based on the infinite assembly of metal-centered building units with organic linkers. Due to their complex porous systems of cavities or tunnels, this class of crystalline solids, commonly named metal−organic frameworks (MOF) or coordination polymers, may have industrial promising applications on the area of molecular adsorption, separation, catalysis, drug delivery, .... From the chemical point of view, a large number of studies has reported the reactivity of organic polycarboxylates with metallic elements from the different blocks of the periodic table. Among them, uranium has attracted special attention, since its crystal chemistry reveals a wide variety of coordination states, which give rise to a large diversity of topologies. Most of the contributions described the use of uranium(VI) with different types of polycarboxylate ligands, such as aliphatic or aromatic ones, resulting in the formation of uranyl−organic frameworks (UOF).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

A considerable interest has been focused on the synthesis of mixed organic-inorganic architectures exhibiting extended networks based on the infinite assembly of metal-centered building units with organic linkers. Due to their complex porous systems of cavities or tunnels, this class of crystalline solids, commonly named metal-organic frameworks (MOF) or coordination polymers, may have industrial promising applications on the area of molecular adsorption, separation, catalysis, drug delivery, .... From the chemical point of view, a large number of studies has reported the reactivity of organic polycarboxylates with metallic elements from the different blocks of the periodic table. Among them, uranium has attracted special attention, since its crystal chemistry reveals a wide variety of coordination states, which give rise to a large diversity of topologies. Most of the contributions described the use of uranium(VI) with different types of polycarboxylate ligands, such as aliphatic or aromatic ones, resulting in the formation of uranyl-organic frameworks (UOF).

elements.content: In this context, different compounds have been isolated with different benzene-containing polycarboxylates by using either a low temperature synthesis route (evaporation−recrystallization) or a hydrothermal route under mild conditions (T < 250 °C). One of the members of the aromatic dicarboxylate series, the phthalic acid (1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid, noted hereafter 1,2-bdc) was specifically investigated, since it is incorporated in many materials encountered in everyday life and therefore observed in the ecology cycle of the environment. Several studies mentioned the interaction of the phthalate species with uranium in solution in order to understand its reactivity and chemical behavior in nuclear wastes, for instance. The crystallization of such uranyl−phthalate complexes gave rise to the formation of different phases. Indeed, one hydrated uranyl phthalate has been fully characterized by means of single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis by Charushnikova et al. This compound UO2(H2O)(1,2-bdc)·H2O crystallizes in triclinic symmetry, at room temperature. Another contribution also reported the occurrence of a second form with a trigonal system obtained upon heating at 175 °C, but its atomic structure was not detailed.
elements.clean_text: In this context, different compounds have been isolated with different benzene-containing polycarboxylates by using either a low temperature synthesis route (evaporation-recrystallization) or a hydrothermal route under mild conditions (T < 250 °C). One of the members of the aromatic dicarboxylate series, the phthalic acid (1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid, noted hereafter 1,2-bdc) was specifically investigated, since it is incorporated in many materials encountered in everyday life and therefore observed in the ecology cycle of the environment. Several studies mentioned the interaction of the phthalate species with uranium in solution in order to understand its reactivity and chemical behavior in nuclear wastes, for instance. The crystallization of such uranyl-phthalate complexes gave rise to the formation of different phases. Indeed, one hydrated uranyl phthalate has been fully characterized by means of single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis by Charushnikova et al. This compound UO2(H2O)(1,2-bdc)⋅H2O crystallizes in triclinic symmetry, at room temperature. Another contribution also reported the occurrence of a second form with a trigonal system obtained upon heating at 175 °C, but its atomic structure was not detailed.

elements.content: This paper deals with the study of the chemical system phthalate−uranyl−water under mild hydrothermal conditions. The variation of the reactional mixture pH is particularly investigated, and two structural types of uranyl phthalates have been isolated and characterized. The first one is the previously mentioned trigonal phase UO2(H2O)(1,2-bdc)·0.32H2O (1), and the second one is obtained in the presence of potassium hydroxide, corresponding to K(UO2)3O(OH)(H2O)(1,2-bdc)2 (2). The replacement of the potassium by ammonium cations led to the crystallization of the isotypic compound (NH4)(UO2)3O(OH)(H2O)(1,2-bdc)2 (3). The structures of the three compounds have been characterized by X-ray diffraction techniques and infrared and luminescence spectroscopies. Thermogravimetric analyses are also discussed as well as their thermal decomposition at high temperature under inert atmosphere.
elements.clean_text: This paper deals with the study of the chemical system phthalate-uranyl-water under mild hydrothermal conditions. The first one is the previously mentioned trigonal phase UO2(H2O)(1,2-bdc)⋅0.32H2O (1), and the second one is obtained in the presence of potassium hydroxide, corresponding to K(UO2)3O(OH)(H2O)(1,2-bdc)2 (2). The replacement of the potassium by ammonium cations led to the crystallization of the isotypic compound (NH4)(UO2)3O(OH)(H2O)(1,2-bdc)2 (3). The structures of the three compounds have been characterized by X-ray diffraction techniques and infrared and luminescence spectroscopies. Thermogravimetric analyses are also discussed as well as their thermal decomposition at high temperature under inert atmosphere.

elements.content:
Caution! Uranyl nitrate UO2(NO3)2·6H2O is a radioactive and chemically toxic reactant; thus, precautions with suitable care and protection for handling such substances should be followed.

The compounds have been hydrothermally synthesized under autogenous pressure using 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr type autoclaves from a mixture of uranyl nitrate hexahydrate (UO2(NO3)2·6H2O, Merck 99%), phthalic acid (1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid or 1,2-H2bdc, Acros Organics, 99%), potassium hydroxide (KOH, Prolabo, 85%), ammonia solution (Prolabo, 28%), and deionized water. The starting chemical reactants are commercially available and have been used without any further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

Caution! Uranyl nitrate UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O is a radioactive and chemically toxic reactant; thus, precautions with suitable care and protection for handling such substances should be followed.

The compounds have been hydrothermally synthesized under autogenous pressure using 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr type autoclaves from a mixture of uranyl nitrate hexahydrate (UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O, Merck 99%), phthalic acid (1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid or 1,2-H2bdc, Acros Organics, 99%), potassium hydroxide (KOH, Prolabo, 85%), ammonia solution (Prolabo, 28%), and deionized water. The starting chemical reactants are commercially available and have been used without any further purification.

elements.content: UO2(H2O)(1,2-bdc)·0.32H2O (1): a mixture of 502 mg (1 mmol) of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O, 83 mg of (0.5 mmol) phthalic acid, 40 mg of (0.6 mmol) KOH, and 5 mL (278 mmol) of H2O was placed in a Parr bomb and then heated statically at 200 °C for 24 h. The solution pH was 1.85 before the reaction and 1.68 at the end. The resulting yellow product was then filtered off, washed with water, and dried at room temperature. In the absence of potassium hydroxide, only a clear yellowish solution is observed. 1 was analyzed with a scanning electron microscope (Hitachi S-3400N) and shows a typical hexagonal shaped elongated crystal of millimeter size (Figure ). Elemental analysis, observed (calc): C 20.9% (21.0%); H 1.4% (1.4%).

elements.content: K(UO2)3O(OH)(H2O)(1,2-bdc)2 (2): a mixture of 502 mg (1 mmol) of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O, 83 mg (0.5 mmol) of phthalic acid, 105 mg (1.6 mmol) of KOH, and 5 mL (278 mmol) of H2O was placed in a Parr bomb and then heated statically at 200 °C for 24 h. The solution pH was 2.22 before the reaction and 2.07 at the end. The resulting yellow product was then filtered off, washed with water, and dried at room temperature. Here, the KOH amount was adjusted in order to get pure phase 2. It gives crystallites with a specific shape of 100−200 μm (Figure ). Elemental analysis, observed (calc): C 15.5% (15.6%); H 0.9% (0.9%).

elements.content: (NH4)(UO2)3O(OH)(H2O)(1,2-bdc)2 (3): a mixture of 502 mg (1 mmol) of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O, 83 mg (0.5 mmol) of phthalic acid, 0.24 mL (3.6 mmol) of NH3, and 4.76 mL (264 mmol) of H2O was placed in a Parr bomb and then heated statically at 200 °C for 24 h. The solution pH was 2.68 before the reaction and 2.41 at the end. The resulting yellow product was then filtered off, washed with water, and dried at room temperature. Here, the NH3 amount was adjusted in order to get pure phase 3. It gives crystallites with a specific shape of 80−300 μm (Figure ). Elemental analysis, observed (calc): C 15.8% (15.9%); N 1.2% (1.2%); H 1.5% (1.2%).

elements.content: Crystals were selected under a polarizing optical microscope and glued on a glass fiber for a single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiment. X-ray intensity data were collected on a Bruker X8-APEX2 CCD area-detector diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) with an optical fiber as collimator. Several sets of narrow data frames (20 s per frame) were collected with ω scans. Data reduction was accomplished using SAINT V7.53a. The substantial redundancy in data allowed a semiempirical absorption correction (SADABS V2.10) to be applied, on the basis of multiple measurements of equivalent reflections. The structure was solved by direct methods, developed by successive difference Fourier syntheses, and refined by full-matrix least-squares on all F 2 data using the SHELX program suite with the WINGX interface. Hydrogen atoms of the benzene ring were included in calculated positions and allowed to ride on their parent atoms. For compound 1, the occupancy factor of the free water molecule was set at 0.33, in agreement with the value found from thermogravimetric analysis. The final refinements include anisotropic thermal parameters of all non-hydrogen atoms. The crystal data are given in Table . is available in CIF format.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction

Crystals were selected under a polarizing optical microscope and glued on a glass fiber for a single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiment. X-ray intensity data were collected on a Bruker X8-APEX2 CCD area-detector diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) with an optical fiber as collimator. Several sets of narrow data frames (20 s per frame) were collected with ω scans. Data reduction was accomplished using SAINT V7.53a. The substantial redundancy in data allowed a semiempirical absorption correction (SADABS V2.10) to be applied, on the basis of multiple measurements of equivalent reflections. The structure was solved by direct methods, developed by successive difference Fourier syntheses, and refined by full-matrix least-squares on all F 2 data using the SHELX program suite with the WINGX interface. Hydrogen atoms of the benzene ring were included in calculated positions and allowed to ride on their parent atoms. For compound 1, the occupancy factor of the free water molecule was set at 0.33, in agreement with the value found from thermogravimetric analysis. The final refinements include anisotropic thermal parameters of all non-hydrogen atoms. The crystal data are given in Table .  is available in CIF format.

Fluorescence spectra (see ) were measured on a SAFAS FLX-Xenius spectrometer between 400 and 800 nm, equipped with a xenon lamp.

ResultsStructure Description

UO2(H2O)(1,2-bdc)·0.32H2O (1) exhibits a one-dimensional structure built up from the connection of the uranium-centered polyhedra linked to each other through the phthalate ligands (Figure ). There exists one unique crystallographical site for uranium surrounded by seven oxygen atoms. Two of them have typical short U−O distances, related to the uranyl bond (UO = 1.760(3) and 1.771(3) Å) and have an expected nearly 180° angle around the uranium cation. Perpendicular to the double uranyl bonds, four carboxyl oxygen atoms (U−O = 2.356(3)−2.408(3) Å) and one water oxygen atom (in the terminal position) are linked to uranium cation, in a pentagonal plane, resulting in a (UO2)O4(H2O) pentagonal bipyramid (Figure , left). This 7-fold coordination was commonly reported in the uranium crystal chemistry. The bond valence calculations give a value of 0.43 for the terminal oxygen (U−O7 = 2.487(4) Å), which is close to the expected value for aquo species (0.4). The coordination polyhedra are connected to each other through two carboxylate groups from two distinct phthalate ligands in order to form corrugated six-membered rings of pentagonal bipyramids around the 3̅ axis at 0 0 0. One of the uranyl bonds (UO1) as well as the terminal water molecule (U−OH2) of each uranium coordination polyhedron are oriented toward the center of the 6-ring. The uranyl bond points alternatively upward or downward from the hexagonal plane with an angle of 19.54(1)°. The second carboxylate arm of each phthalate also links to each other two distinct uranyl cations belonging to an adjacent 6-ring (connected alternatively up or down from the hexagonal plane of uranyl cations). The carboxylate groups of the phthalates adopt a bidentate bridging mode with a syn−anti configuration (μ4-η1:η1:η1:η1) and ensure the cohesion between the 6-ring building units along the c axis. Such a connection mode generates infinite tubelike one-dimensional motifs running along the ternary axis (Figure ), with the tubular wall decorated by the (UO2)O4(H2O) pentagonal bipyramids. The phthalate benzene ring and the second uranyl bonding (UO2) point outside the molecular tubes. The structure results from the hexagonal packing of these nanotubes in the (a,b) plane, with preferred interactions between UO bonds and hydrogen from benzene rings (UO2···H = 2.735(3) Å). The internal free diameter of the tube is estimated to be 3.5 Å (only based on the ionic radius of 1.35 Å for oxygen). The tubular motifs encapsulate free water molecules statistically disordered on two special positions (0 0 z) at the center (0.33 H2O per UO2 unit). Weak hydrogen bond interactions occur between the terminal aquo species bonded to uranium and the free water (OW···H2O−U = 3.15(5) Å).

elements.content: Indeed, this circular arrangement of actinides cations is not new, since an identical structure has been previously reported with neptunium(VI). Grigoriev and co-workers reported the single crystal structure of the neptunium phthalate NpO2(H2O)(1,2-bdc)·0.33H2O with cell parameters (a = b =30.50(2), c = 5.849(4), R3̅) close to our uranium-based phase. The uranyl phthalate parent was only mentioned, but its structural analysis was not given. Moreover, this tubular structure was more recently observed in an uranyl formate by Thuéry and also in phenyl phosphonates by Clearfield, 15 years ago. Our uranyl phhtalate is a new example of such circular one-dimensional cylinders delimited by six cations. It is interesting to notice that the tendency of uranium to generate a tubular assembly was also found in a variant form with phenylphosphonate or selenates. In the latter, the tubelike ring is larger and contains 10 uranyl centers. It is assumed that the bulky organic amine (butylamine) used for its synthesis would play a role of the structure directing agent in order to orient the formation of cylinders with larger diameter compared to the other members of this series encapsulating water.

elements.content: Compounds 2 and 3, A(UO2)3O(OH)(H2O)(1,2-bdc)2 (A = K, NH4), are identical and built up from two distinct inorganic building blocks connected to each other through the phthalate ligands. The first building unit, lying on an inversion center (1/2 0 0, 1d), is a dinuclear species containing two uranyl cations in a 7-fold coordination (Figure ). It corresponds to one independent crystallographic site (U1) for uranium, which has two short uranyl bonds (UO = 1.773(9)−1.778(10) Å and 1.764(4)−1.767(4) Å for 2 and 3, respectively). The coordination of the UO2 2+ cation is completed by five oxygen atoms located in a pentagonal plane. Two of them (O13) are sharing between two uranium atoms through a common edge. Bond valence calculations give values close to 1.07 and 1.18 for this oxygen, reflecting the occurrence of a μ2-hydroxo group bridging the uranyl cations. Two other oxygen atoms (O9 and O11) belong to the carboxylate groups of the two different phthalate linkers, with U−O distances ranging from up to 2.364(4) and 2.382(8) Å. The last oxygen (O15) is in the terminal position of the equatorial plane (U1−O15 = 2.439(8) and 2.438(4) Å for 2 and 3, respectively) and is assigned to an aquo species (bond valence of 0.47). It results in a coordination surrounding for uranium (UO2)O2(μ2-OH)2(H2O) corresponding to a dimeric block (UO2)2O4(μ2-OH)2(H2O)2. The distances between the uranium centers are 3.8534(7) and 3.8662(3) Å (for 2 and 3, respectively) within the dimer. The existence of such a dinuclear unit with 7-fold coordination sharing a hydroxo edge is not so common for uranium, although there are more examples with uranyl in an 8-fold surrounding. Previous works report such a dimer in an uranyl formate or uranyl mixed formate-oxalate, for instance. The second building unit is tetranuclear (Figure ), containing two independent crystallographical uranium sites and lying on another inversion center (1/2 1/2 1/2, 1 h). It consists of two uranium cations in 8-fold coordination (U2) with a hexagonal bipyramid environment and two uranium cations in 7-fold coordination (U3) with a pentagonal bipyramid polyhedron. This tetramer has a relatively flat configuration with the uranyl bonds (UO = 1.774(9)−1.783(9) Å and 1.767(4)−1.786(5) Å for 2 and 3, respectively) pointing upward and downward from the equatorial plane. In the 8-fold coordination, four of the oxygen atoms of the hexagonal equatorial plane belong to carboxylate groups (U−O = 2.561(7)−2.656(7) Å and 2.555(3)−2.660(3) Å for 2 and 3, respectively) and the last remaining oxygen atoms are oxo groups, which are also bonded to a third uranium atom (U−O = 2.214(7)−2.258(7) Å and 2.220(4)−2.260(3) Å for 2 and 3, respectively). The assignment of the latter oxygen to a μ3-oxo species (O6) is in good agreement with the bond valence calculation considerations (calc: 2.07). In the 7-fold coordination, the four remaining oxygen atoms of the pentagonal bipyramid are from carboxylates (U−O = 2.379(7)−2.442(7) Å and 2.373(3)−2.442(3) Å for 2 and 3, respectively), and two of them are common to the adjacent uranium cation U2 (O7 and O8). The U2-centered polyhedra share a common oxo edge to each other, which also share a common oxo edge to the U3-centered polyhedra, forming the tetranuclear unit (UO2)4(μ3-O)2O12. Two distinct uranium−uranium distances are observed within this tetramer (U2···U2 = 3.7135(6) and 3.7228(3) Å, and U2···U3 = 3.9659(5) and 3.9691(3) Å, for 2 and 3, respectively). Such a structural motif is known for uranyl crystal chemistry and was previously encountered in different phases. Other variations of tetramers were also described with only a 7-fold coordination for uranium. One of the carboxylate arms of the two distinct phthalate ligands bridges the uranium cations via both chelate and monodentate connection modes toward the uranyl cations U2 and U3, respectively. The second carboxylate arm has a syn−anti bidentate bridging mode between the 7-fold coordinated uranyl cations of the tetranuclear and dinuclear units. The phthalate groups are pentadentate, adopting a configuration μ5-η1:η2:η1:η1. The organic linker allows for a connection of the two types of building bricks along the direction [011], generating infinite anionic organic−inorganic chains [(UO2)3O(OH)(H2O)(1,2-bdc)2]− (Figure ). The electroneutrality of the structure is ensured by the presence of potassium or ammonium cations which are located along the a axis and connect the chains to others along that direction (Figure ). There are two crystallographic sites for potassium or ammonium cations: one of them (K2 or N2) is 50% statistically occupied. K1 is located nearby the dinuclear uranyl unit on special position 1a (0 0 0) and is 10-fold coordinated with K−O distances ranging from 2.906(10) to 3.224(8) Å. The second K2, located between two tetranuclear uranyl units, is 6-fold coordinated with K−O distances in the range 2.809(11)−2.994(11) Å. These KO6 and KO10 polyhedra generate pillars between the inorganic chains and form a layered neutral network K(UO2)3O(OH)(H2O)(1,2-bdc)2 with the benzene rings of the phthalate groups perpendicularly pointing along the (b,c) plane. The three-dimensional cohesion of the structure is ensured by the occurrence of weak π−π interactions between the benzene rings, with C···C distances close to ≈3.8 Å. An identical arrangement is also observed for the ammonium form, except the occurrence of hydrogen bond interactions (N···O = 2.92−3.21 Å) with some oxygen of the inorganic building units.

elements.content: These two compounds are new examples of uranyl phthalates. Indeed, two other uranyl phthalates were previously described by Charushnikova et al.: it concerns a phase crystallizing in a triclinic symmetry with a different hydration state, compared to the trigonal phase (1). This solid, UO2(H2O)(1,2-bdc)·H2O obtained after heating at 125 °C for 2 h, is built up from the connection of pentagonal bipyramids (UO2)O4(H2O) with the phthalate ligands in order to generate infinite chains intercalated by free water molecules. These chains consist of a strict double alternation of uranyl-centered polyhedra and phthalates. The second uranyl phthalate was reported with different countercations (K+, NH4 +, Cs+) and contains a similar tetranuclear unit (UO2)4(μ3-O)2O8. The only difference comes from the existence of a second building dimeric block present in compounds 2 and 3, which induces the connection with the different bricks to form infinite chains, instead of discrete molecular species in the Charushnikova’s phases. Crystals of the latter were grown at room temperature after a heating process at 70 °C of the solution mixture. For both compounds, the synthesis condition plays a drastic role, since elevated temperature seems to direct other structural atomic arrangement by playing on the water content (UO2(H2O)(1,2-bdc)·H2O6 → UO2(H2O)(1,2-bdc)·0.32H2O (1)) or the organization of structural building blocks: isolated (0D) tetranuclear units are formed at low temperature, and 1D assembly of tetranuclear together with dinuclear units (2 and 3) are obtained after a hydrothermal treatment at 200 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

These two compounds are new examples of uranyl phthalates. Indeed, two other uranyl phthalates were previously described by Charushnikova et al.: it concerns a phase crystallizing in a triclinic symmetry with a different hydration state, compared to the trigonal phase (1). This solid, UO2(H2O)(1,2-bdc)⋅H2O obtained after heating at 125 °C for 2 h, is built up from the connection of pentagonal bipyramids (UO2)O4(H2O) with the phthalate ligands in order to generate infinite chains intercalated by free water molecules. These chains consist of a strict double alternation of uranyl-centered polyhedra and phthalates. The second uranyl phthalate was reported with different countercations (K+, NH4 +, Cs+) and contains a similar tetranuclear unit (UO2)4(μ3-O)2O8. The only difference comes from the existence of a second building dimeric block present in compounds 2 and 3, which induces the connection with the different bricks to form infinite chains, instead of discrete molecular species in the Charushnikova's phases. Crystals of the latter were grown at room temperature after a heating process at 70 °C of the solution mixture. For both compounds, the synthesis condition plays a drastic role, since elevated temperature seems to direct other structural atomic arrangement by playing on the water content (UO2(H2O)(1,2-bdc)⋅H2O6 → UO2(H2O)(1,2-bdc)⋅0.32H2O (1)) or the organization of structural building blocks: isolated (0D) tetranuclear units are formed at low temperature, and 1D assembly of tetranuclear together with dinuclear units (2 and 3) are obtained after a hydrothermal treatment at 200 °C.

elements.content: For a given temperature, the other influential parameter is the reaction pH. Indeed, several hydrothermal reactions have been carried out at 200 °C as a function of the concentration of basic solution (KOH or NH3). It should be noted that pH was not measured during the hydrothermal treatment although it is possible to estimate its value by using in situ liquid NMR spectroscopy, for instance. Nevertheless, the scan of the different pH values before (or after) the reaction is a first approximate probe, which gave us an analysis of its effect on the nature of phases in the chemical system UO2 2+/1,2-bdc/H2O. With KOH, the formation of the hexagonal nanotubular phase (1) was observed for pH values between 1.0 and 1.4. From pH = 1.4, the second phase K(UO2)3O(OH)(H2O)(1,2-bdc)2 (2) appears and can be obtained as a pure compound from pH = 1.7 up to pH = 3. When using NH3, similar behavior has been observed with a lower limit of the pH, where the hexagonal phase (1) starts to appear at pH = 0.9. The domain where the two phases 1 and 3 occur is 1.5−2.0, and the upper limit where the phase (NH4)[(UO2)3O(OH)(H2O)(1,2-bdc)2] (3) starts to become impure is pH = 3.0. For both cases, under highly acidic conditions, no crystallization is visible and only a clear yellow solution is obtained. For pH greater than 3, a powdered mixture together with 2 or 3 was obtained and could not be identified in this study. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the pH evolution are given as . These results point out well the pH effect on the condensation process for uranyl cations under hydrothermal conditions. In very acidic solution, only the expected isolated UO2L5 (L for oxo ligand from carboxylate group or water) species are observed from the crystal structure analysis in our work. The increase of pH induces a hydrolysis reaction resulting in an oligomerization process with the formation of hydroxo or oxo bridges between the uranyl centers. Dinuclear and tetranuclear units are thus obtained together with a higher coordination for the uranyl cation (8-fold coordinated) (Figure ). This observation is a nice illustration of the pH effect for the formation of uranyl carboxylate with different oligomerization states. This was recently reported and well documented by Rowland and Cahill for the formation of different uranyl oxalates and squarates. For the latter study, these authors found that the isolated UO2L5 species occur from pH 1 up to 7, but between 5.5 and 8, a trinuclear motif (UO2)3O4L6 was identified before the monodimensional polymerization into infinite chains of UO2L5 polyhedral units.

elements.content: The thermogravimetric curve (Figure ) of compound 1 shows different weight loss steps. The first event occurring from room temperature up to 100 °C is assigned to the departure of free water molecules encapsulated within the nanotubes of the structure. A weight loss of 1.25% is observed and corresponds to 0.32H2O per UO2 formula unit. This H2O/UO2 ratio is identical to that observed by single-crystal analysis (0.33). The second step up to 210 °C (obs: 3.7%) is attributed to the removal of the water molecule (calc: 3.9%) bonded to the 7-fold coordinated uranium centers. The last event (obs: 32.6%), up 420 °C, corresponds to the decomposition of the organic linker (calc: 35.7%). The powder XRD pattern of the final residue indicates a mixture of uranium oxides U3O8 (pdf number: 15-0007) and UO2 (pdf number: 73-2293), with an observed remaining weight loss of 62.5% (calc: 60.0%, based on the U3O7 formula). The thermal behavior of compound 1 was also tested in inert atmosphere (argon) in a furnace at 1000, 1200, and 1400 °C. For the different temperatures, only the formation of uranium dioxide UO2 (pdf number: 73-2293) has been observed.

elements.content: The TG curve (Figure ) of compound 3 exhibits a main weight loss event (30.3%) starting from 210 °C up to 410 °C, co-rresponding to the decomposition of the structure with the removal of the phthalate ligands (calc: 27.5%). A first step (≈2.7%) occurring from 210 °C up to 300 °C is visible and might be partly due to the departure of water species (1H2O corresponds to 1.5%). The remaining weight loss at 1000 °C is 69.7%, which is in good agreement with a calculated value based on UO2 (calc: 67.1%). The powder XRD pattern final residue showed the formation of uranium dioxide UO2 (pdf number: 73-2293).

elements.content: The fluorescence experiments were performed under excitation at 365 nm at room temperature, on the three phases (1−3) as well as on an uranyl dinitrate hexahydrate (UO2(NO3)2·6H2O) sample for comparison. The spectrum (see ) of compound 1 exhibits the typical six well-defined signals located at 482.0, 497.4, 519.9, 544.3, 570.9, and 600.3 nm. The successive bands correspond to the electronic transitions S 11 → S 00 and S 10 → S 0v (v = 0−4), respectively. As expected, the band spacing for between the S 11 → S 00 and S 10 → S 00 transitions is 642 cm−1 and those between the S 10 → S ov ones are 862 ± 7 cm−1. The latter value, which is related to the Raman symmetric vibrations characteristic of the double uranyl bond OUO, agrees with those reported in the literature. The fluorescence spectrum of the uranyl dinitrate hexahydrate also has the same signature with six well-defined bands. From the consideration of the most intense one located at 508.1 nm, the fluorescence spectrum of compound 1 is red-shifted of 11.8 nm, which is previously reported in other uranyl dicarboxylates by Cahill for instance.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence

The fluorescence experiments were performed under excitation at 365 nm at room temperature, on the three phases (1-3) as well as on an uranyl dinitrate hexahydrate (UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O) sample for comparison. The spectrum (see ) of compound 1 exhibits the typical six well-defined signals located at 482.0, 497.4, 519.9, 544.3, 570.9, and 600.3 nm. The successive bands correspond to the electronic transitions S 11 → S 00 and S 10 → S 0v  (v = 0-4), respectively. As expected, the band spacing for between the S 11 → S 00 and S 10 → S 00 transitions is 642 cm-1 and those between the S 10 → S ov  ones are 862 ± 7 cm-1. The latter value, which is related to the Raman symmetric vibrations characteristic of the double uranyl bond OUO, agrees with those reported in the literature. The fluorescence spectrum of the uranyl dinitrate hexahydrate also has the same signature with six well-defined bands. From the consideration of the most intense one located at 508.1 nm, the fluorescence spectrum of compound 1 is red-shifted of 11.8 nm, which is previously reported in other uranyl dicarboxylates by Cahill for instance.

elements.content: The fluorescence spectra of compounds 2 and 3 (see ) are almost similar but do not have the resolution observed for compound 1. Indeed, only a broad signal is observed between 480 and 600 nm with two fine peaks located at 527 and 537 nm. Shoulders are also visible for the potassium-containing sample 2 at 500, 562.4, and 590 nm. No precise interpretation can be done for such compounds. However, it seems that a structural arrangement of uranium centers isolated by aromatic ligands (1) would favor the observation of a well-defined signature of the fluorescence spectrum. In the case of oligomeric building units, such as those found in compounds 2 and 3, the electronic transitions are not so well-defined.

Shoulders are also visible for the potassium-containing sample 2 at 500, 562.4, and 590 nm. No precise interpretation can be done for such compounds. However, it seems that a structural arrangement of uranium centers isolated by aromatic ligands (1) would favor the observation of a well-defined signature of the fluorescence spectrum. elements.content: Three uranyl phthalates have been synthesized by using hydrothermal treatment at 200 °C in water solvent. Depending on the reaction pH, two structural types have been isolated. In a narrow pH domain (0.9−1.5): a trigonal 1D nanotubular structure (1) is observed with discrete pentagonal bipyramids UO2L5 (L = oxo group from carboxylate or water species) linked through the phthalate ligands. At higher pH values (up to 3), a second phase appears: it is built up from the connection of dinuclear (UO2)2(μ2-OH)2L6 and tetranuclear (UO2)4(μ3-O)2L12 units to generate infinite chains. 7- and 8-fold coordinated uranium occurs in the tetramer, and only 7-fold coordinated uranium occurs in the dinuclear unit. These chains are intercalated by potassium or ammonium cations depending on the nature of the base used for the pH variation (KOH or NH3). These observations indicate the polymerization process of the cationic uranyl species as a function of the hydrolysis rate related to the reaction pH. Larger building blocks are observed at solid state when increasing pH, whereas isolated uranyl species are present under highly acidic conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Three uranyl phthalates have been synthesized by using hydrothermal treatment at 200 °C in water solvent. Depending on the reaction pH, two structural types have been isolated. In a narrow pH domain (0.9-1.5): a trigonal 1D nanotubular structure (1) is observed with discrete pentagonal bipyramids UO2L5 (L = oxo group from carboxylate or water species) linked through the phthalate ligands. At higher pH values (up to 3), a second phase appears: it is built up from the connection of dinuclear (UO2)2(μ2-OH)2L6 and tetranuclear (UO2)4(μ3-O)2L12 units to generate infinite chains. 7- and 8-fold coordinated uranium occurs in the tetramer, and only 7-fold coordinated uranium occurs in the dinuclear unit. These chains are intercalated by potassium or ammonium cations depending on the nature of the base used for the pH variation (KOH or NH3). These observations indicate the polymerization process of the cationic uranyl species as a function of the hydrolysis rate related to the reaction pH. Larger building blocks are observed at solid state when increasing pH, whereas isolated uranyl species are present under highly acidic conditions.

cln_elements.content:
UO2(H2O)(1,2-bdc)·0.32H2O (1): a mixture of 502 mg (1 mmol) of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O, 83 mg of (0.5 mmol) phthalic acid, 40 mg of (0.6 mmol) KOH, and 5 mL (278 mmol) of H2O was placed in a Parr bomb and then heated statically at 200 °C for 24 h. The solution pH was 1.85 before the reaction and 1.68 at the end. The resulting yellow product was then filtered off, washed with water, and dried at room temperature. In the absence of potassium hydroxide, only a clear yellowish solution is observed. 1 was analyzed with a scanning electron microscope (Hitachi S-3400N) and shows a typical hexagonal shaped elongated crystal of millimeter size (Figure ). Elemental analysis, observed (calc): C 20.9% (21.0%); H 1.4% (1.4%).

K(UO2)3O(OH)(H2O)(1,2-bdc)2 (2): a mixture of 502 mg (1 mmol) of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O, 83 mg (0.5 mmol) of phthalic acid, 105 mg (1.6 mmol) of KOH, and 5 mL (278 mmol) of H2O was placed in a Parr bomb and then heated statically at 200 °C for 24 h. The solution pH was 2.22 before the reaction and 2.07 at the end. The resulting yellow product was then filtered off, washed with water, and dried at room temperature. Here, the KOH amount was adjusted in order to get pure phase 2. It gives crystallites with a specific shape of 100−200 μm (Figure ). Elemental analysis, observed (calc): C 15.5% (15.6%); H 0.9% (0.9%).

(NH4)(UO2)3O(OH)(H2O)(1,2-bdc)2 (3): a mixture of 502 mg (1 mmol) of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O, 83 mg (0.5 mmol) of phthalic acid, 0.24 mL (3.6 mmol) of NH3, and 4.76 mL (264 mmol) of H2O was placed in a Parr bomb and then heated statically at 200 °C for 24 h. The solution pH was 2.68 before the reaction and 2.41 at the end. The resulting yellow product was then filtered off, washed with water, and dried at room temperature. Here, the NH3 amount was adjusted in order to get pure phase 3. It gives crystallites with a specific shape of 80−300 μm (Figure ). Elemental analysis, observed (calc): C 15.8% (15.9%); N 1.2% (1.2%); H 1.5% (1.2%).
